newsitem.title: GREECE: GREEK PAST BUDGETS SHOW TARGET-OUTCOME DIVERGENCE.
newsitem.headline: GREEK PAST BUDGETS SHOW TARGET-OUTCOME DIVERGENCE.

text.p: Greece will unveil its 1997 budget
on Friday, coined the toughest in 15 years by National Economy
Minister Yannos Papandoniou, in a bid to near the fiscal
Maastricht target and make it to the EMU in 2000 or 2001.
Greece wants to reduce its general government budget deficit
to 4.2 percent of GDP in 1997 from an expected 7.6 percent in
1996 and the central government budget deficit to 6.2 percent of
GDP from an expected 9.3 percent.
The budget deficit reduction package relies on a combination
of new, heavier taxes, the closing of existing tax loopholes and
reigning in planned spending to about 1997 average inflation --
projected at 6.5 percent from an anticipated 8.5 percent in
The GDP growth is forecast to speed up to 3.3 percent from
an expected 2.6 percent in 1996 and 2.0 percent in 1995.
But a closer look at Greece's 1994-1996 budget performance
reveals that the central government budget deficit target
diverged from the actual deficit by a large margin. In fact,
targets were below actual budget deficit outcomes.
Final central government primary surplus figures were close
to target in 1994 and exceeded it in 1995.
The contrasting behaviour of the overall central budget
deficit and the primary surpluses points to the accounting
treatment of interest payments on public debt as a likely
explanatory variable in the budget equation.
The general government budget deficit targets also diverged
but target deficits ended higher than final outcomes.
This can be largely explained by unrecorded operating
surlpuses of state entities mainly due to the 1992 social
insurance reform that was incorporated in budget figures in
But the central government budget and primary surplus
figures are calculated on an administrative basis and the
general government budget figures on a national accounts basis
which means that the comparison of the two is incorrect.
The central government budget figures do not include accrued
and capitalised interest as well as the non-cash coverage of
state guarantees to public sector utilities.
Another interesting development that has worked towards
reducing budget deficits as a percent of GDP is the better-than-
projected performance of the GDP which reflects upward revisions
as well as a higher volume of goods and services in the economy.
